text.tspan: Tuition classes have become a common pursuit in Indian students' lives due to the
enormous curriculum studied in preparation for the competitive and career-defining
examinations (Verma et al., 2002). The study conducted by Deb et al. (2015) shows that more
than half of parents appoint three to four private tutors for their children. On days when there are
no tuition classes, there are art or music lessons. According to the National Sample Survey Office
(NSSO) (2014), 26% of Indian school students in 2014 were receiving private coaching. Besides
these extra tutorials, students face excessive homework from school (Verma et al., 2002),
diminishing time for recreational activities and socialization, further adding to the stress.
With an increase in academic pressure, students often sacrifice their health to maintain
high grades by dedicating more time to study. This researcher experienced multiple sudden
fainting episodes while preparing for the 10th-grade board exams with study time exceeding 15
hours a day. Various students recorded such stress reactions in the research conducted by Parikh
et al. (2015), with one student describing it to be "like a mind attack" (p. 5). According to the
National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) (2018) of India, the country witnessed 130,000 student
suicides in 2018. This means, on average, nearly twenty-eight students committed suicide every
24 hours during 2018.
With the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic and a nationwide lockdown lasting more than
two months, the shutdown of all educational institutions has left the student body uncertain of
future events. The situation occurs at the same time as university entrance tests and final school
examinations at the conclusion of the academic year. With this sense of uncertainty, the unique
conditions of the COVID-19 situation have left numerous questions unanswered, concerning
how the lockdown has affected academic stress among students. This researcher hypothesizes
